author: JOEY KAUFMAN
title: UCLA: Alford has more options with improved depth
text:
BY JOEY KAUFMAN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 2, 2015 Updated: 11:31 p.m. LOS ANGELES – UCLA men’s basketball coach Steve Alford needs to adjust to his team’s depth in the coming weeks.
It’s hardly a troublesome development, though.
As the Bruins opened practice for the 2015-16 season Friday afternoon, Alford found himself leading a team with 11 scholarship players, the most in the third-year coach’s tenure and a group that presents him with a handful of lineup options to sort out before the regular-season opener on Nov.13 against Monmouth.
“We’re a little bit deeper than we have been,” Alford said.
UCLA, which is coming off consecutive Sweet 16 appearances in the NCAA Tournament and finished 22-14 last season, lost two of its top players to the NBA. Guard Norman Powell led the team in scoring (16.4 points per game) and versatile forward Kevon Looney was the leading rebounder (9.4 per game).
But the Bruins return a bevy of talent, including Bryce Alford, the team’s second-leading scorer from a season ago (15.4), and welcome several new faces. Six-foot-10 swingman Jonah Bolden sat out last season with eligibility issues, and freshman guards Aaron Holiday and Prince Ali are four-star recruits.
The 6-1 Holiday is a point guard and the younger brother of former Bruins guard Jrue Holiday. The 6-3 Ali is more of a two-guard.
“We know we’re going to have to play a little differently with our lineups,” Alford said. “We have some versatility this year that I haven’t had.”
That starts with Bolden, who likely replaces Looney in the starting lineup as a stretch-four, or what Alford refers to as the team’s “big guard.” They might also play 7-foot sophomore center Thomas Welsh alongside 6-9 big man Tony Parker, who can slide over to power forward, or vice versa.
“It’s just going to be a matchup problem (for opponents),” said Parker, now a senior.
Welsh and Parker are the team’s top returning rebounders.
Welsh got some extra experience this summer playing for the U.S. men’s team that won the gold medal at the FIBA U19 World Championships in Greece in July.
“It’s going to be hard for people to guard him,” Parker said. “He’s so tall, and he’s getting really, really agile.”
Other combinations include playing four guards together on the floor, including Holiday, Ali, Alford and Isaac Hamilton. Bolden could be swapped in, as well.
Steve Alford hopes to see what rotations work best moving forward.
